Aikido.name: Aikido

image.attribution: Magyar Balázs, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
image.alt_text: Two aikido practitioners demonstrate the shihonage technique, with one applying a wrist and arm throw to the other.

description: Aikido is a defensive martial art that emphasizes blending with an opponent’s movement rather than meeting force with force. It focuses on control, balance, and redirection.
Aikido was developed in Japan by Morihei Ueshiba and is rooted in traditional Japanese martial arts and philosophy. Its goal is self-defense while minimizing harm to others.
Students learn joint locks, throws, pins, and safe falling techniques. Training also develops posture, coordination, and awareness.
People practice Aikido for self-control, focus, and personal growth rather than competition.
benefits: Teaches control and redirection of force.
Improves balance, posture, and coordination.
Encourages calmness and situational awareness.
Promotes non-violent conflict resolution.

BrazilianJiu-Jitsu.name: Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu

image.attribution: © John Lamonica, CC BY-SA 3.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
image.alt_text: Two Brazilian jiu-jitsu practitioners compete on the mat during a match.

description: Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu is a grappling martial art that focuses on ground fighting and submission techniques.
It developed in Brazil from Japanese Judo and Jiu-Jitsu and emphasizes leverage and technique over strength.
Students learn takedowns, positional control, escapes, and submissions such as chokes and joint locks.
People practice BJJ for self-defense, competition, fitness, and confidence.
benefits: Teaches effective ground fighting and control.
Builds problem-solving and adaptability.
Improves strength, endurance, and flexibility.
Allows smaller practitioners to overcome larger opponents using technique.

JapaneseJujutsu.name: Japanese Jujutsu

image.attribution: Unknown, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons
image.alt_text: Students practicing Japanese Jujutsu with rifles at an agricultural school.

description: Japanese Jujutsu (or Jujutsu/Koryū Jujutsu) is a traditional grappling martial art emphasizing throws, joint locks, pins, and control techniques.
It was developed by the samurai of feudal Japan as a practical method for unarmed self-defense and battlefield combat.
Training includes throws, joint manipulations, pins, and minimal strikes (atemi) primarily to set up grappling techniques.
People practice Japanese Jujutsu to improve balance, coordination, self-defense skills, and an understanding of historical martial traditions.
JapaneseJujutsu.competition_format: Traditional schools focus on practice and kata; modern competitions exist in some schools
benefits: Develops balance, coordination, and body control.
Builds versatile grappling and self-defense skills.
Teaches efficient use of leverage and technique over strength.
Preserves historical Japanese martial arts knowledge.
famous_practitioners: Kanō Jigorō (student and adapter of jujutsu into Judo)

Judo.name: Judo

image.attribution: Korea.net / Korean Culture and Information Service (Photographer name), CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
image.alt_text: Judo athlete Kim Jaebum performing a throw during an Olympic match.

description: Judo is a grappling martial art and Olympic sport focused on throws, pins, and control.
It was developed in Japan by Jigoro Kano from traditional Jiu-Jitsu with an emphasis on efficiency and education.
Students learn powerful throws, ground pins, submissions, and safe falling techniques.
People practice Judo for discipline, fitness, and competitive sport.
benefits: Develops strong balance and throwing mechanics.
Teaches efficient use of energy and leverage.
Improves coordination and full-body strength.
Builds discipline and respect through structured training.

Sambo.name: Sambo

image.attribution: President.az, CC BY 4.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
image.alt_text: Two athletes compete in sambo at the 2015 European Games, with one performing a throw.

description: Sambo is a grappling martial art known for its aggressive throws and submission techniques.
It was developed in the Soviet Union by combining elements of Judo and traditional wrestling styles.
Training includes takedowns, leg locks, pins, and ground control.
People practice Sambo for competitive grappling, strength, and agility.
benefits: Develops explosive takedowns and transitions.
Improves grip strength and body control.
Teaches aggressive yet technical grappling.
Builds resilience and competitive mindset.

Wrestling.name: Wrestling

image.attribution: U.S. Air Force photo/Joshua Armstrong, Public domain, via Wikimedia Commons
image.alt_text: Two wrestlers compete on the mat during a college wrestling match.

description: Wrestling is a grappling sport that focuses on takedowns, control, and pinning an opponent.
It is one of the oldest combat sports and has existed in many cultures throughout history.
Students learn takedowns, clinching, escapes, and positional control.
People practice wrestling to develop strength, endurance, and mental toughness.
Wrestling.competition_format: Timed matches with points and pins
benefits: Builds exceptional strength and conditioning.
Improves balance, coordination, and explosiveness.
Teaches control of an opponent’s body.
Develops discipline and work ethic through intense training.
